Fig. 10 Enhanced electrocatalytic activity of urchin-like Nb2O5 microspheres by synergistic effects with Pd toward electrooxidation of ethylene glycol in an alkaline medium Liang Qi Investigation Formal analysis Software Visualization 1 Xiaoyu Guo Investigation Formal analysis Software Visualization 1 Xiaoguang Zheng Formal analysis Software Visualization Yuanjiang Wang Software Visualization Yanhong Zhao Conceptualization Methodology Software Data curation Writing - original draft Supervision * Xiaojing Wang Writing - review & editing Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot, 010021, China Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Inner Mongolia University Hohhot 010021 China Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot, 010021, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 The authors contributed equally to this work. They should be considered co-first authors. Graphical abstract Urchin-like niobium oxide (U-Nb2O5) microspheres are obtained using a low-temperature hydrothermal method. The nanosized palladium (Pd) particles loading onto U-Nb2O5 (Pd/U-Nb2O5) microspheres are successfully prepared using a reflux method. X-ray diffraction results imply that the U-Nb2O5 and Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres belong to the orthorhombic phase, and Pd loading does not change the crystalline phase. The average size of nanosized Pd particles loaded is 4.25 nm. In addition, the valence states of Pd on the surface of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres are mainly of a Pd° form. The catalytic activity of the different loading amount Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts is carried out in a 0.5 M KOH and 1 M ethylene glycol (EG). When the usage of palladium acetate is 10 mg (the mass ration of Pd to Nb2O5 is 10 %), the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibits high catalytic activity for the electrooxidation of EG in an alkaline medium. The current density of EG electrooxidation on the Pd/U-Nb2O5 modified glassy carbon electrode is higher than that on commercial Pd/C (10 %). Moreover, the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibits strong anti-CO poisoning ability and good stability for EG oxidation in alkaline medium. After 6000 s, the maintained current density on the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is 12.7 times that on commercial Pd/C. This remarkable performance of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is owing to the synergistic effect between Pd and Nb2O5. The calculation results imply that the synergistic effect improves electron transfer. Keywords Niobium oxide Ethylene glycol oxidation Electrocatalysis Density functional theory 1 Introduction Increasingly more attention is being paid to two serious problems: energy shortage and environmental pollution, caused by dosage of fossil fuels [1–4]. Fuel cells are regarded as clean energy in the 21st century. In the past few decades, hydrogen has been used as a fuel, which has the advantages of a fast reaction rate, being non-toxic, and giving zero pollution. However, hydrogen is not easy to liquefy, storage and transportation are not convenient, and it has a low energy density of 0.53 (kWh·L−1) [5,6]. Therefore, its application is greatly limited. Direct alcohol fuel cells (DAFCs) using small molecule alcohols (methanol, ethanol, EG etc.) as fuels have been widely studied due to their low operating temperatures, environmental friendliness, high theoretical energy densities and the convenient storage and transportation of liquid fuel [7–9]. Among these small molecule alcohol fuels, methanol exhibits the fastest kinetic rate, but it is toxic and crosses the membrane easily to reach the cathode, reducing cell efficiency [10,11]. Ethanol is easily obtained from plants and is non-toxic, but it has a slow kinetic rate and it is difficult to break the CC band [12,13]. EG with a simple C2 structure has a high boiling point (198 °C), making it safe to use [14,15]. Moreover, EG exhibits a lower crossover via the Nafion membrane, a low toxicity and has a high energy density (4800 A L-1) [16,17]. Therefore, direct ethylene glycol fuel cells with EG served as the fuel have potential application prospects. The Pt-based catalysts are known as the most effective electrocatalysts in the anode alcohol oxidation in DAFCs. However, they are not widely used because they are expensive, easily poisoned and scarce [18–23]. Pd is similar to the crystal structure of Pt, and it exhibits a high catalytic activity toward alcohol electrooxidation in an alkaline medium [24,25]. The Pd-based electrocatalysts are a potential alternative to Pt-based materials [15,25]. Many researchers have tried to enhance the catalytic properties of Pd-based electrocatalysts further. For example, Sun et al. found that the PdAu nanoparticles dispersed on the polydopamine functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes exhibited good catalytic activity for EG electrooxidation [26]. Guo et al. studied that the ultrathin PtPdM (M = Ni, Fe, Co) nanosheets bifunction electrocatalysts exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity toward EG or glycerol oxidation and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in alkaline medium [14]. Compared with commercial Pt/C, the multimetallic Pd nanosponges (PdAuNi) had an enhanced electrocatalytic activity for EG and glycerol oxidation in alkaline medium [15]. The nanosized Pd-Ru-Bi alloy particles embedded in the 3D graphene oxide/MOF-199 composites displayed good electrocatalytic activity for EG oxidation, which was attributed to the unique 3D structure and excellent synergistic reaction of trimetallic Pd-Ru-Bi alloys [24]. Zhang et al. found that the hierarchically multi-branched PdRuCu nanoassemblies had good catalytic properties and stability for ethanol and EG electrooxidation [27]. Yang et al. found that the Au@PdAg core-shell nanotubes exhibited good catalytic activity and stability toward methanol oxidation in a basic medium. The remarkable electrocatalytic properties were attributed to their large specific surface area and unique porous morphology [28]. Research shows that the ternary PdCu-SnO2 nanowires promote electrocatalytic performance and strong durability for ethanol oxidation in an alkaline medium, owing to the introducing SnO2 into the nanostructure interface [29]. In addition, the electrocatalyst support plays a very important role in catalysis. In fuel cells, carbon materials are often used as the supports for catalysts [30]. However, they easily corrode and collapse under the operating environment of fuel cells [31,32]. Research has shown that metal oxides have a high corrosion resistance, and strong interaction between metal oxide and metal nanoparticles [33]. Among these metal oxides, Nb2O5 has many advantages. It is environmentally friendly, accessible, low cost and has an excellent chemical and electrochemical stability [34,35]. Moreover, Nb2O5 is a semiconductor with certain conductivity. Therefore, Nb2O5 has potential applications in electrode materials of fuel cells. Research has been undertaken to improve applications in electrode materials of Nb2O5. The improvement of their catalytic performances is a key goal in many applications [36]. For example, Justin et al. found that Pt nanoparticles dispersed Nb2O5 incorporated Vulcan carbon XC-72R exhibited good catalytic properties toward methanol oxidation, and had strong corrosion resistance toward CO-like intermediates. The excellent electrochemical performances were attributed to the synergistic reaction between Pt and Nb2O5 [37]. Research has also shown that Pt nanoparticles supporting the Nb2O5 and carbon nanofiber composite had good catalytic properties for methanol oxidation, owing to the enhanced electrical conductivity and strong connection between the Pt and Nb2O5/C support [38]. Shi et al. reported that box-implanted Nb2O5 nanorods were applied for the anode materials in lithium-ion batteries, and they displayed a good reversible capacity, which was attributed to the regular boxes implanted in Nb2O5 nanorods providing fast transportation paths for Li+ and electrons [39]. Nb2O5 supported Au-Cu catalysts exhibited high activity in oxidation of methanol toward CO2 and glycerol, owing to the synergy between Au and Cu, and the Nb2O5 being active [40]. The air filter Nb2O5 was used as the electrode in the supercapacitors, and showed a high specific capacitance [41]. Nb2O5 has different crystal phases, which demonstrate different electrochemical properties [42–44]. They contain pseudohexagonal, orthorhombic, tetragonal, and monoclinic phases in the heat treatment environment [42,45]. Among these crystal phases, the orthorhombic Nb2O5 shows the best electrochemical properties, owing to the fast ion insertion-extraction reaction and superior cycling stability [46]. In this work, therefore, the orthorhombic phase U-Nb2O5 microspheres with a large specific surface area were synthesized using the low temperature method, and then the nanosized Pd particles were loaded onto the U-Nb2O5 using the reflux method. The different loading amount Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts were prepared by changing the dosage of Pd(Ac)2. The crystal phase, morphology, and components of samples were measured using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Their electrocatalytic properties were carried out using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a 0.5 M KOH solution containing 1 M EG. The electrochemical stability and the resistances of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts were measured with the chronoamperometry (CA) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) techniques. The influence of Pd loading on the microstructure of Nb2O5 was assessed by density functional theory (DFT). 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and preparation of samples In experiments, all materials used were analytical grade without further purification. Ammonium niobium oxalate hydrate NH4[NbO(C2O4)2]·nH2O (99.9 %) was obtained from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. Palladium acetate (Pd(Ac)2, 99.5 %) was obtained from Innochem Technology Co., Ltd., Beijing, China. The ethanol and acetone came from Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd., Tianjin, China. The water used in all experiments was deionized. The urchin-like Nb2O5 nanostructures were synthesized using a low temperature hydrothermal method [47]. Firstly, 1.8 g of NH4[NbO(C2O4)2]·nH2O was dissolved in 70 mL of the mixture of distilled water and ethanol and their volume ratio is 1:1. The above mixture was ultrasonicized for 15 min to obtain a transparent solution. Then, the obtained solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept for 24 h at 180 °C. Next the autoclave was naturally cooled to room temperature. The white powder obtained was centrifuged and washed several times using distilled water. These were dried under 80 °C for 8 h in an oven. Finally, the resulting white urchin-like Nb2O5 (U-Nb2O5) microspheres were obtained after calcination under 550 °C for 2 h. The Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres were synthesized using reflux under acetone and water. Pd(AC)2 was served as the source of the Pd loading. 50 mg of the U-Nb2O5 microspheres were dispersed in the 50 mL deionized water, then, this was ultrasonicized for 5 min, and was magnetically stirred for 60 min to a uniform suspension. This suspension was passed into N2 for 30 min, then heated for 2 h at 85 °C. During refluxing, the different amounts of Pd(Ac)2 were dissolved in 10 mL of acetone, respectively, and added dropwise to the above solution. Then, the NaBH4 aqueous was added dropwise. The amount of Pd(Ac)2 was 5, 8, 10, 12, and 15 mg, respectively. The color of the suspension changed from yellow to black. After 2 h, the powder was centrifuged and washed several times with distilled water. The resulting production of Pd/U-Nb2O5 was obtained after being dried for 12 h under 80 °C. With the different Pd loading, these samples were labeled as 5%Pd/U-Nb2O5, 8%Pd/U-Nb2O5, 10 %Pd/U-Nb2O5, 12 %Pd/U-Nb2O5, and 15 %Pd/U-Nb2O5, respectively (Scheme 1 ) . 2.2 Physical characterizations The crystal phase structure of samples was performed with XRD on a Rigaku DMAX2500, from Japan. The morphology and size of samples were characterized using SEM (S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) and TEM (GZ F20 S Twin, FEI, America). High- resolution TEM was also carried out. The components of samples were analyzed using XPS on an ESCA-LAB MKII apparatus. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements CV and stability tests were carried out on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments Ins., China). Pure Nb2O5 and Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres modified glassy carbon electrodes (GCE, φ =5 mm) were served as the working electrodes. The saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and graphite rod ( φ =5 mm) were served as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The working electrode as follows: 10 μL of Nafion (5 wt%) and 90 μL of ethanol were mixed, and 5 mg of Pd/U-Nb2O5 (or pure U-Nb2O5) was added into this mixture. Then, this mixture was stirred for 12 h to obtain a uniform suspension. The suspension was dropped on the polished GCE, and dried for 4 h at 60 °C. Finally, the Pd/U-Nb2O5 and pure Nb2O5 modified GCEs (Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE, U-Nb2O5@GCE) were prepared, and the electrocatalytic activity was measured in 0.5 M KOH solution containing 1 M EG. For comparison, the commercial Pd/C modified GCE (Pd/C@GCE) was obtained using the same method. During the electrochemical experiments, all the electrolytes were continuously filled with N2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the U-Nb2O5 and different loading amount Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres. The sharp characteristic diffraction peaks of Nb2O5 were observed and belong to the orthorhombic phase. It was found that the prepared Nb2O5 was consistent with the unit of JCPDS: 00-030-0873. No impurity peak was identified, implying that a pure phase of Nb2O5 was obtained. With the Debye-Scherrer formula ( D = k λ / cos θ ), the crystal size of Nb2O5 can be calculated from the (001) crystal plane to be approximately 23.8 nm. The curves (b–f) show the XRD patterns of 5%, 8%, 10 %, 12 %, and 15 % Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. When the loading amount of the Pd nanoparticles was low, the diffraction peaks of Pd were not observed. When the dosage of Pd(Ac)2 reached 15 %, the characteristic peaks could be observed to be increasing with the Pd loading amount, and the diffraction peaks at 39.9°corresponded with the cell unit (JCPDS: 96-101-1111). 3.2 Morphology characterization Fig. 2 presents the SEM images of the U-Nb2O5 (a, b) and Pd/U-Nb2O5 (c, d) (in the following description, 10 %Pd/U-Nb2O5 was recorded as Pd/U-Nb2O5) with different magnifications. Fig. 2a and b show that the shape of pure Nb2O5 obtained after calcination at 550 °C. It is perfectly urchin-like, and the diameter is about 500 nm. The surface of the spherical structure is rugged with many long sticks, called an urchin-like Nb2O5 microsphere. The long sticks of surface were growth cross each other form many holes with the different size, which made their specific area makes large. The large specific area results form high catalytic activity, which is very important for the performance of the catalyst. Fig. 2c and d show SEM images of Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres with different magnifications. Compared with the pure urchin-like Nb2O5 microsphere, the morphology of the urchin-like Nb2O5 microsphere does not change after the nanosized Pd particles are loaded. The nanosized Pd particles were not found in these microsphere images, possibly because the loaded Pd nanoparticles are small. In order to further verify whether Pd is loaded onto U-Nb2O5 microspheres, an energy diffraction spectrum (EDS) is performed, and shown in Fig. 2e. From the EDS data, it can be seen that the U-Nb2O5 sample contained a Pd component. The EDS mapping is shown in Fig. 2f, where the red, green and blue regions represent the distribution of Nb, O, and Pd, respectively. The result implies that nanosized Pd particles are uniformly loaded on the U-Nb2O5 microspheres. The content of Pd was about 1.1 wt% from the energy spectrum, which is lower than the usage of Pd(Ac)2. The morphology and size of loaded Pd on the surface of the U-Nb2O5 microspheres were analyzed with TEM, and shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3a–c show the TEM images of Pd/U-Nb2O5 under different magnifications. From these images, we can see that the nanosized Pd particles were uniformly loaded onto the U-Nb2O5 microspheres; a finding that is in agreement with SEM and EDS results. The nanosized Pd particles were mainly loaded on the long sticks of the U-Nb2O5 microspheres, and it was beneficial to the contact between Pd and EG molecule. Fig. 3d shows that the HRTEM image of Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts, and an interplanar spacing of 3.93 Å was due to the plane (001) of Nb [46]. On the other hand, the interplanar spacing of 2.30 Å was assigned to the plane (111) of Pd [48,49]. We proved that the Pd nanoparticles have been successfully loaded onto the U-Nb2O5 microspheres. Fig. 3e shows the particle size distribution of Pd loaded onto U-Nb2O5. The size of Pd nanoparticles was mostly distributed between 2.75 and 6.75 nm with an average size of 4.25 nm. Moreover, the loading amount of Pd nanoparticles was tested using EDS, XPS, and inductively coupled plasma (ICP). The results showed that the Pd content of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 (the dosage of Pd(Ac)2 is 10 %) electrocatalyst was 1.1 wt%, 1.7 wt% and 1.8 wt%, respectively. 3.3 XPS analysis and microstructure of Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts To further confirm the components and valence state of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst, XPS tests were carried out, as shown in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4a shows the XPS survey spectra of the pure U-Nb2O5 and Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. From this figure, it can be seen that the pure U-Nb2O5 contains O, Nb, and C. Meanwhile, Pd/U-Nb2O5 contains O, Nb, C, and Pd. It can be proved that Pd nanoparticles have been successfully loaded onto the surface of U-Nb2O5 microspheres. Here, C is the source of the test environment. Fig. 4b shows the XPS spectrum of the Pd 3d orbital. It is found that the binding energies (BEs) of Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 are 334.92 and 340.20 eV, respectively, attributed to be the Pd° form [50–52]. On the other hand, the BEs of Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 at 337.09 and 342.30 eV, respectively, implied that the valence states of Pd are +2 form [50–52]. It can be seen that there are two valence states of Pd loaded onto the surface of U-Nb2O5. Moreover, zero valence of Pd was the main form of existence, and the mass ratio of Pd° was 72.1 %. Fig. 4c is the XPS spectrum of the Nb 3d orbital. The BEs of Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2 were 206.86 and 209.61 eV for U-Nb2O5, respectively, and indicated that the valence state of Nb is +5 form [38,53]. These values shifted negatively to 206.85 and 209.60 eV for Pd/U-Nb2O5, respectively. This result indicates that a synergistic effect occurs between Pd and Nb2O5. Fig. 4d shows a comparison of the high-resolution XPS spectra of the O 1s orbitals of U-Nb2O5 and Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. The BEs of the O 1s in U-Nb2O5 are located at 529.92, 531.04, and 532.19 eV, which in turn correspond to the lattice oxygen, defective oxygen, and adsorbed oxygen, respectively [54,55]. After loading Pd, the BE of the defective oxygen shifted negatively by 0.06 eV (from 531.04 eV to 530.98 eV). The result indicates that a synergistic effect occurs between Pd and Nb2O5, which is similar to the previous report [56]. Rodríguez-Padŕon et al. studied that the Ag@CN (g-C3N4) nanocomposites with α-rich proteins exhibited the outstanding electrocatalytic properties for hydrogen evolution reaction, which was associated with the unique synergistic interactions between Ag nanoparticles, hemoglobin tertiary, and the graphitic carbon nitride networks [56]. This is owing to the electron transfer between Pd and Ta2O5, and it was further confirmed by following DFT calculation. On the another hand, the Pd-O-Nb bonds were formed between the loading Pd and Nb2O5, enhancing the adsorption of Nb2O5 for −OH. Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity of Nb2O5 was enhanced after Pd was loaded. To investigate the influence of Pd loading on the microstructure of Nb2O5, DFT was carried out using Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) in Materials Studio [57]. Fig. 5 a shows the 2 × 2 × 2 supercell calculation model of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst, and the Pd-cluster contains 13 atoms which is stable. Fig. 5b shows the charge density difference of Nb2O5 after Pd loading. In this figure, the blue region (the region near Pd atoms) represents the electron loss area, and the red region (the region near O atoms) represents the electron enrichment area. We can be known that the electron transfer occurred between Pd and Nb2O5, in agreement with the XPS results. The result implied that the electron mobility is increased in the complex region of Pd and Nb2O5. The synergistic effect occurs between Pd and Nb2O5, and the conductivity of U-Nb2O5 is enhanced after Pd loading. The excellent Pd loading effect was mainly due to the electron transfer of Pd and O atoms which has been reported previously [58]. The fast electron transfer between Pd and Nb2O5 leads to efficient electrocatalytic performance, which is similar to the pervious literature [59,60]. Ahsan et al. researched that the NiCu bimetallic confined in a porous carbon network exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity for oxygen reduction, oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions, which was due to the fast electron transfer between the NiCu nanoparticles and the carbon network [59]. Therefore, we investigated the catalytic activity of Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. 3.4 Electrocatalytic activity of Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts CV is one of the important methods evaluating the electrocatalytic activity of electrocatalysts. The electrocatalytic activity of U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts was carried out in a 0.5 M KOH solution and 1 M EG, shown in Fig. 6 a. The scan rate is 50 mV s−1. During the whole scanning process, two peaks were observed. The peak at -0.18 V is due to the oxidation of EG, and another peak at -0.32 V is attributed to be the oxidation of intermediate products of ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) [61,62]. Fig. 6b shows that CV performances on the Pd/U-Nb2O5 and commercial Pd/C electrocatalysts modified GCEs in 0.5 M KOH solution and 1 M EG at 50 mV s−1. The peak current density at -0.10 V on the Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE is 0.133 A mg−1, which is 1.48 folds that on the commercial Pd/C@GCE (0.090 A mg−1). This result implies that electrocatalytic activity of Pd/U-Nb2O5 is superior to commercial Pd/C for EG oxidation in an alkaline medium. The Pd loading could enhance the electrocatalytic properties of the U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst, due to the electron transfer between Pd and Nb2O5. The result implied that the synergistic reaction occurred between Pd and Nb2O5. The previous reported that the outstanding properties of hydrogen evolution reaction for Ag@CN nanocomposites were associated with the unique synergistic interactions between Ag and the graphitic carbon nitride networks [56]. However, the electrochemical active surface area of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is lower than that of commercial Pd/C. This phenomenon is similar to previous repot [63]. The reason might be that the pores formed by the long stickscross were blocked by loading Pd particles, resulting in the decrease of specific surface area. The ratio of the forward peak current density (j f) and the backward peak current density (j b) is a significant parameter to evaluate the poisoning resistance. The values of j f/j b were 2.95 and 1.12 for Pd/U-Nb2O5 and commercial Pd/C electrocatalysts. The higher the value of j f/j b, the stronger the anti-poisoning ability of the electrocatalyst [64]. The value of j f/j b on the Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE was larger than that on Pd/C@GCE. This result indicated that the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst had an excellent anti-poisoning ability. In order to further prove the role of the carrier Nb2O5 in the catalytic reaction, we carried out an anti-CO poisoning test on the catalyst, referred to as the CO stripping test, and shown in Fig. 7 . At the same time, the CO produced by the alcohols in the oxidation process is firmly adsorbed on the surface of Pd to form Pd-CO groups. Thus, electrons in the Nb2O5-OH group can be transferred to the Pd-CO group, which can promote the combination of the O in Nb2O5-OH with the CO in Pd-CO to form CO2. The released Pd can continue to oxidize the alcohol. The substance, in this way, forms a cyclic process on the surface of the catalyst to improve the ability of CO anti-toxicity. In Fig. 7, it can be seen that the initial potential of the catalyst Pd/U-Nb2O5 is -0.30 V and that of the commercial Pd/C is -0.23 V, indicating that the catalyst Pd/U-Nb2O5 has a lower oxidation potential than the commercial Pd/C toward CO oxidation. Moreover, during the oxidation of CO, the peak current density on Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE reached 161 mA mg−1. However, the value on commercial Pd/C@GCE was only about 60 mA mg−1. The peak current density on Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE was larger than that on commercial Pd/C@GCE, implying that the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts had strong anti-poisoning for CO. In addition, the CO stripping test of the U-Nb2O5 samples was carried out in same condition, and shown in Fig. S1. From the figure, we can be seen that the U-Nb2O5 samples exhibited anti-CO poisoning property. To test the electrooxidation properties of EG on the Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE, CVs were carried out at different scan rates in a 0.5 M KOH solution and 1 M EG, shown in Fig. 8 a. It is seen that the peak current density increased with an increase in the scan rate. In contrast, in these peaks of EG oxidation shift positively with an increase in scan rate. The results confirm that the oxidation process of EG is a charge-transfer controlled electrochemical process [65]. The proportional relationship between of the peak current densities at -0.10 V and the square root of the scan rate is shown in Fig. 8b. The linearity suggests that the electrooxidation of EG was the diffusion-controlled process onto the Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE [66,67]. The linearity relationship is j = 0.495v 1/2 + 0.010, and the slope value is 0.495. The CV is tested on Pd/C@GCE in 0.5 M KOH solution and 1 M EG at different scan rates, and shown in Fig. S2. The relationship of the peak current densities and the square root of the scan rates is linear. The slope value on commercial Pd/C@GCE is 0.098, which is less than that on Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE. This result indicates that the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibited faster kinetics than the commercial Pd/C for EGOR. Therefore, the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst had excellent catalytic activity for the electrooxidation of EG in an alkaline medium. In addition, the effect of the Pd loading amount on the catalytic activity of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. The CV performances were carried out on the different amounts of Pd loading U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts in a 0.5 M KOH solution and 1 M EG at 50 mV s−1, and shown in Fig. S3. From the figure, it can be seen that the peak current densities were low when the dosages of Pd(Ac)2 were 5% and 8%. This is because the loading amount of Pd is low. When the dosage of Pd(Ac)2 was 10 %, the peak current density reached the highest value. However, the peak current density decreased when the dosages of Pd(Ac)2 were 12 % and 15 %. This is because the Pd nanoparticles agglomerated, and the electrochemical active surface area change was small. Fig. S4 shows the TEM image of the 12 %Pd/U-Nb2O5 and 15 % Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres. From this figure, it can be clearly seen that the Pd nanoparticles are agglomerated and the particle size becomes large. To further investigate the stability of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst, it was subjected to a stability test with a duration of 6000 s using long lasting CA (Fig. 9 ) for oxidation of EG. The voltage of the CA measurement is set to -0.10 V. At the beginning, the current density decayed rapidly due to the accumulation of intermediates during the oxidation of EG. The carbonaceous materials forming on the surface of the electrode made the electrocatalysts coated on it poisoned. Moreover, after 6000 s, Pd/U-Nb2O5@GCE maintained a higher current density than the commercial Pd/C@GCE, and it is 12.7 times that of commercial Pd/C@GCE. Loading Pd nanoparticles combined with Nb2O5 to form a covalent bond, accelerating electron transfer and enhancing the anti-poisoning ability of the catalyst. In addition, Nb2O5 absorbed hydroxyl groups to form Nb2O5-OH, which further reacted with Pd-CO to form CO2. The active site was released, improving the stability of Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts. EIS test was usually used to study the electron transfer kinetics of electrocatalysts. Fig. 10 shows Nyquist diagrams of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 and U-Nb2O5 modified GCEs in 0.1 M KOH solution and 1 M EG. The curve of high frequency region shows a semicircle, which represents the charge transfer resistance. The smaller the diameter, the smaller the resistance, which proves the fast electron transfer kinetics at the electrode/electrolyte interface [68]. In this figure, the diameter of semicircle of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 plot is smaller than that of U-Nb2O5, indicating that the resistance of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is smaller. The values of the resistance for the Pd/U-Nb2O5 and U-Nb2O5 samples are 601 and 2960 Ω, respectively. The result implied that a synergistic effect occurs between Pd and Nb2O5, and it exhibits a fast electron transfer. 4 Conclusion In summary, the U-Nb2O5 microspheres were synthesized successfully using a low temperature hydrothermal method. The Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts were obtained using a reflux method. The nanosized Pd particles with an average size of 4.25 nm were uniformly loaded on the U-Nb2O5 microspheres, and the loading Pd was mainly of the Pd° form. The Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity toward the electrooxidation of EG in an alkaline medium. When the dosage of Pd(Ac)2 was 10 mg, the electrocatalytic activity of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst was high. Moreover, its electrocatalytic activity was superior to that of commercial Pd/C. The outstanding electrocatalytic activity attributed to the fact that the bond formed of Pd with Nb2O5 to accelerate the electron transfer rate. Nb2O5 can form many oxygen-containing functional groups, accelerating the oxidation of intermediate carbonaceous materials formed on the electrocatalyst surface. Moreover, the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts presented an excellent anti-poisoning ability, which is very suitable for fuel cell operating environments. coredata.dc:description: Urchin-like niobium oxide (U-Nb2O5) microspheres are obtained using a low-temperature hydrothermal method. The nanosized palladium (Pd) particles loading onto U-Nb2O5 (Pd/U-Nb2O5) microspheres are successfully prepared using a reflux method. X-ray diffraction results imply that the U-Nb2O5 and Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres belong to the orthorhombic phase, and Pd loading does not change the crystalline phase. The average size of nanosized Pd particles loaded is 4.25 nm. In addition, the valence states of Pd on the surface of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 microspheres are mainly of a Pd° form. The catalytic activity of the different loading amount Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalysts is carried out in a 0.5 M KOH and 1 M ethylene glycol (EG). When the usage of palladium acetate is 10 mg (the mass ration of Pd to Nb2O5 is 10 %), the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibits high catalytic activity for the electrooxidation of EG in an alkaline medium. The current density of EG electrooxidation on the Pd/U-Nb2O5 modified glassy carbon electrode is higher than that on commercial Pd/C (10 %). Moreover, the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst exhibits strong anti-CO poisoning ability and good stability for EG oxidation in alkaline medium. After 6000 s, the maintained current density on the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is 12.7 times that on commercial Pd/C. This remarkable performance of the Pd/U-Nb2O5 electrocatalyst is owing to the synergistic effect between Pd and Nb2O5. The calculation results imply that the synergistic effect improves electron transfer.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced electrocatalytic activity of urchin-like Nb2O5 microspheres by synergistic effects with Pd toward electrooxidation of ethylene glycol in an alkaline medium
